caseStudy.title: Primary Service Connection for GERD
caseStudy.excerpt: Early-2000s Marine veteran • Repeated in-service stomach complaints • Chronic reflux after deployment
caseStudy.content_html: The VA denied GERD because there was no formal in-service diagnosis. The STRs contained few notations of “stomach pain” and prescription of antacids.
caseStudy.challenge: The VA denied GERD because there was no formal in-service diagnosis. The STRs contained few notations of “stomach pain” and prescription of antacids.
caseStudy.solution:
• STR notations of GI discomfort
  • Post-service GERD diagnosis.
caseStudy.results:
• Highlighted repeated GI complaints in STRs
  • Explained pathophysiology of chronic reflux
  • Demonstrated post-service continuity through medical records
  • Connected dietary exposure during deployment to symptom onset
caseStudy.key_takeaway: Once the updated medical rationale and continuity-of-symptom documentation were submitted, the veteran later received a favorable VA decision granting primary service connection for GERD.
